Peter, I'm glad to see you're still thinking about this important question.=
  You make some interesting observations.  I think you're probably right th=
at trying to correlate node density to CPPN complexity is not the best appr=
oach.  On the other hand, making changes in node density correlated somewha=
t with fitness seems potentially sensible.  But it still doesn't seem to an=
swer the big question of where within the substrate to add the nodes?  Or w=
ould you just increase overall density uniformly?  My concern is that biolo=
gical brains did not increase in density (which for them may just mean size=
) uniformly.  That is, some parts of the brain got bigger while others did =
not.  That would seem to imply that a substrate should be able to add densi=
ty selectively to specific regions that evolution decides on itself.  Or pe=
rhaps your idea incorporates that kind of regional growth somehow already?
=

About saturation of the sigmoid- that is indeed an important issue.  Right=
 now we are investigating some techniques to mitigate saturation, which I t=
hink will end up being effective and also which will facilitate the kind of=
 massive substrate complexification that would be really cool to see in the=
 future.

Still, we still do not have any elegant algorithm to evolve the s=
ubstrate, though I am confident it will be possible.

ken

--- In neat@yaho=
ogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" <petar_chervenski@...> wrote:
>
> Hi all!
>=
 
> I was gone for a while, but before a day or so I had some spare time to=
 continue my research about automated substrate evolution. 
> 
> My latest =
research so far ended up with a system capable of approximating any spatial=
 CPPN picture with a developing mesh based on the Growing Neural Gas algori=
thm. While this worked well and could be used for evolving substrate config=
urations right away, there was still a problem about deciding the right num=
ber of nodes for particular individuals. With GNG, it is more like a proble=
m of deciding when to stop development or approximation of the CPPN picture=
. 
> 
> When we discussed the issue some time ago, I had the idea that CPPN=
 complexity can be directly linked to substrate density. More complex CPPN =
=3D more dense substrate. This seems like a solution but it I think it is a=
ctually a bad idea. A CPPN containing many nodes and links does not always =
produce a complex pattern in space. It can be an entirely white or black pi=
cture, due to genetic defects. Plus, it is not sure that the problem requir=
es that many nodes to be solved - the CPPN may have enormous complexity but=
 producing a simple well-shaped picture that solves it. 
> 
> So what I thi=
nk now is, that substrate density should be related to fitness instead. How=
 exactly? Well here is my idea. 
> 
> All individuals start with a minimal =
number of nodes in the substrate, say 50. There will be a mutation increasi=
ng the number of nodes with about 0%-10% or decreasing with 0%-10%. The mut=
ation rate will vary across species. Species that are stagnating for too lo=
ng time will have the probability of this mutation increased - because they=
 may just lack the number of nodes to solve the problem. Or have too many n=
odes. 
> 
> You know, there is a problem with having the number of nodes in=
creasing and this is the over saturation of the sigmoid. Increasing the den=
sity with 2x will have very big impact if the weights are not altered, espe=
cially in case recurrence is present. How can we cope with that? 
> 
> I do=
n't have any experimental data yet, I am too busy programming some bullshit=
 but please tell me if this ideas make sense to you. 
> 
> Peter
>
